title: How to Clean a Deep Freezer

steps.headline: Make room for the food in your refrigerator freezer.
steps.description: Make as much room as you can in your refrigerator freezer for the food you will remove from the deep freezer. One way to make room is to throw away all items that are outdated or unrecognizable in your deep freezer and your refrigerator's freezer. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				Work quickly if you don't want to defrost the freezer. Chris Willatt, the owner of Alpine Maids, says: "Set the freezer to its hottest setting, then take everything out,  including all of the food and any removeable racks or shelves. Wash the racks with soap and water in the sink and set them aside to dry. Then, wipe down the inside of the freezer with a microfiber cloth and water or an all-purpose cleaner. When you're finished, put the racks back and get your food back into the freezer as quickly as possible."

steps.headline: Prepare coolers with ice.
steps.description: If there isn't enough room in your refrigerator freezer, you will need to find another cold place to keep the food from the deep freezer. Set aside several large coolers and put a layer of ice in the bottom of each cooler.

steps.headline: Relocate the food.
steps.description: Take the food from the deep freezer and put it in your refrigerator freezer. Place the remaining food in the coolers and then put a layer of ice on top of the food. If you still need more space for the food, you can store it in the refrigerator itself. If you are cleaning on a day with freezing temperatures, you can try sitting the food outside while you clean the deep freezer.

steps.headline: Consult the owners' manual.
steps.description: Every freezer is different. Take a moment to read through the owners' manual to figure out exactly how you should go about defrosting your freezer. If you don't have a physical copy of the manual, try visiting the manufacturer's website to locate a digital copy.

steps.headline: Turn off and unplug the deep freezer.
steps.description: You will need to make sure your deep freezer is turned off and disconnected from its power source. This will ensure that all of the ice inside the deep freezer melts.

steps.headline: Open the freezer doors.
steps.description: You will need to leave the doors of your deep freezer open while it defrosts. This will help the freezer completely defrost more efficiently.

steps.headline: Prepare for a lot of water.
steps.description: The ice in your deep freeze will melt into water and could potentially make a huge mess. Try placing large towels on each of the shelves in the freezer as well as on the floor surrounding the freezer. You can also catch melting water by placing large pans on the freezer shelves.

steps.headline: Check the progress every 20 minutes.
steps.description: To prevent an unwanted mess, you will want to monitor the progress. Check in every 20 minutes and replace wet towels or empty pans that have filled with water.

steps.headline: Let the deep freezer defrost until all the ice is melted.
steps.description: The size and model of your deep freezer will determine how long it will take for the appliance to defrost. For smaller models, this could take less than an hour. Larger deep freezers may take several hours.

steps.headline: Consider speeding up the process.
steps.description: Check your freezer manual to see if the manufacturer recommends or cautions against speeding up the defrosting process. Try using a hair dryer, fan, or space heater to speed up the melting process. You could also try using a putty knife to chip around the edges of larger chunks of ice.

steps.headline: Wipe out the melted water.
steps.description: Once all the ice in the deep freezer melts, remove any towels or pans from inside the freezer. Then take a clean towel and wipe out all the excess moisture and water from the interior of the deep freezer.

steps.headline: Remove and clean any shelving.
steps.description: If your deep freezer has removable shelves, take them out. Then clean the shelves with warm, soapy water and allow them to dry before placing them back inside the deep freezer.

steps.headline: Clean the inside of the deep freezer.
steps.description: Wash down the inside of the deep freezer with warm soapy water. You can also mix one cup (240 mL) of water, one teaspoon white vinegar, and one teaspoon dish soap in a spray bottle. Spray the solution on the freezer walls and floor and then wipe down with a wet cloth.

steps.headline: Wipe down the outside of the freezer.
steps.description: After cleaning the interior of the deep freezer, you will want to wipe down the exterior. Use a cleaning spray or warm, soapy water to wipe down the front, back, and sides of the deep freezer.

steps.headline: Dry the deep freezer with a towel.
steps.description: After cleaning the interior and exterior of the deep freezer, dry it with a clean towel. Make sure you remove all the moisture from the interior of the freezer. This will prevent new ice from forming.

steps.headline: Turn the freezer on for 6-8 hours before adding food.
steps.description: Once the freezer is completely dry, close the doors and turn the freezer back on. Most manufacturers advise that you leave the deep freezer on for six to eight hours before you place frozen items inside. This time varies between models, so consult your owner's manual or the manufacturer.

text: Removing Food from the Freezer Make room for the food in your refrigerator freezer. Make as much room as you can in your refrigerator freezer for the food you will remove from the deep freezer. One way to make room is to throw away all items that are outdated or unrecognizable in your deep freezer and your refrigerator's freezer. EXPERT TIP																															Chris Willatt																Cleaning Guru								Chris Willatt is the owner and founder of Alpine Maids, a cleaning agency in Denver, Colorado started in 2015. Alpine Maids has received Angie's List Super Service Award for three years in a row since 2016 and has been awarded Colorado's "Top Rated Local House Cleaning" Award in 2018. Chris Willatt			Cleaning Guru				Work quickly if you don't want to defrost the freezer. Chris Willatt, the owner of Alpine Maids, says: "Set the freezer to its hottest setting, then take everything out,  including all of the food and any removeable racks or shelves. Wash the racks with soap and water in the sink and set them aside to dry. Then, wipe down the inside of the freezer with a microfiber cloth and water or an all-purpose cleaner. When you're finished, put the racks back and get your food back into the freezer as quickly as possible." Prepare coolers with ice. If there isn't enough room in your refrigerator freezer, you will need to find another cold place to keep the food from the deep freezer. Set aside several large coolers and put a layer of ice in the bottom of each cooler. Relocate the food. Take the food from the deep freezer and put it in your refrigerator freezer. Place the remaining food in the coolers and then put a layer of ice on top of the food. If you still need more space for the food, you can store it in the refrigerator itself. If you are cleaning on a day with freezing temperatures, you can try sitting the food outside while you clean the deep freezer. Defrosting the Freezer Consult the owners' manual. Every freezer is different. Take a moment to read through the owners' manual to figure out exactly how you should go about defrosting your freezer. If you don't have a physical copy of the manual, try visiting the manufacturer's website to locate a digital copy. Turn off and unplug the deep freezer. You will need to make sure your deep freezer is turned off and disconnected from its power source. This will ensure that all of the ice inside the deep freezer melts. Open the freezer doors. You will need to leave the doors of your deep freezer open while it defrosts. This will help the freezer completely defrost more efficiently. Prepare for a lot of water. The ice in your deep freeze will melt into water and could potentially make a huge mess. Try placing large towels on each of the shelves in the freezer as well as on the floor surrounding the freezer. You can also catch melting water by placing large pans on the freezer shelves. Check the progress every 20 minutes. To prevent an unwanted mess, you will want to monitor the progress. Check in every 20 minutes and replace wet towels or empty pans that have filled with water. Let the deep freezer defrost until all the ice is melted. The size and model of your deep freezer will determine how long it will take for the appliance to defrost. For smaller models, this could take less than an hour. Larger deep freezers may take several hours. Consider speeding up the process. Check your freezer manual to see if the manufacturer recommends or cautions against speeding up the defrosting process. Try using a hair dryer, fan, or space heater to speed up the melting process. You could also try using a putty knife to chip around the edges of larger chunks of ice. Cleaning the Freezer Wipe out the melted water. Once all the ice in the deep freezer melts, remove any towels or pans from inside the freezer. Then take a clean towel and wipe out all the excess moisture and water from the interior of the deep freezer. Remove and clean any shelving. If your deep freezer has removable shelves, take them out. Then clean the shelves with warm, soapy water and allow them to dry before placing them back inside the deep freezer. Clean the inside of the deep freezer. Wash down the inside of the deep freezer with warm soapy water. You can also mix one cup (240 mL) of water, one teaspoon white vinegar, and one teaspoon dish soap in a spray bottle. Spray the solution on the freezer walls and floor and then wipe down with a wet cloth. Wipe down the outside of the freezer. After cleaning the interior of the deep freezer, you will want to wipe down the exterior. Use a cleaning spray or warm, soapy water to wipe down the front, back, and sides of the deep freezer. Dry the deep freezer with a towel. After cleaning the interior and exterior of the deep freezer, dry it with a clean towel. Make sure you remove all the moisture from the interior of the freezer. This will prevent new ice from forming. Turn the freezer on for 6-8 hours before adding food. Once the freezer is completely dry, close the doors and turn the freezer back on. Most manufacturers advise that you leave the deep freezer on for six to eight hours before you place frozen items inside. This time varies between models, so consult your owner's manual or the manufacturer.
